awd_titl_txt: Probing Anomalous Nanoparticle Dynamics in Polymer Solutions with Simulation and Experiment
awd_abstract_narration:
Nanoparticles are used as additives to make composite materials with specific mechanical, thermal, and optical properties.  Controlling the transport and distribution of the nanoparticles during processing is critical to obtaining desired properties.  This award will support research into the transport and distribution of nanoparticles in polymeric fluids.  The project will focus on the diffusion and flow-driven transport of nanoparticles in the case where the nanoparticles are comparable in size to the size of the polymer molecules in the fluid.  The research will combine experiments that image particle motions in polymeric fluids with computer simulations that reveal various mechanisms of nanoparticle dynamics and interactions between nanoparticles and polymers.  Results of the research will lead to improved predictions of nanoparticle transport, which will enhance a variety of important technological applications, including wastewater reuse, drug delivery, and advanced materials processing for energy storage and generation.  The research team will participate in several activities that engage K-12 students and the general public in science and engineering, including a hands-on team-based design program for students in grades 7-10, the GRADE summer camp for women and students from underrepresented groups, and Energy Day and Earth Day festivals for the general public in Houston.  In addition, the researchers will disseminate results of the project to local industrial scientists and engineers at the Texas Soft Matter Meeting.

This project will deploy particle-imaging experiments and computational models to understand coupling between particle-polymer dynamics in solution. To achieve this objective, advanced simulation techniques will be integrated with imaging and particle synthesis to identify physical mechanisms dictating coupling between particles and similarly-sized polymers in solution, and to determine effects of particle anisotropy on particle-polymer dynamics. Stochastic rotational dynamics simulations will be used to measure the structure and dynamics of particles and polymers on experimentally relevant time scales. Simulation predictions for dynamics will be tested against experimental measurements in carefully chosen nanoparticle-polymer mixtures. This combination of simulation and experiment will elucidate the effects of particle shape, size, and anisotropy on the dynamics of these mixtures and thereby transform understanding of the physical processes controlling coupled transport in multicomponent complex fluids. Results will lead to modifications of existing theories to account for changes in dynamical coupling on these scales and provides the necessary strong foundation for future studies of flow-driven nanoparticle transport

Intellectual Merit:

The focus of this NSF PMP grant was to investigate the effects of macromolecular crowding on the motions of nanoscale particles. Nanoparticles are of a small enough size (here, below 1 micron) such that interactions with the surrounding solvent molecules can cause them to move and diffuse when dispersed in solutions. They are widely used in industrial products (such as inks, paints, coatings, and personal care products) and are increasingly employed in advanced manufacturing to impart novel functionality (optical, electrical, mechanical properties). In these formulations nanoparticles are commonly mixed with macromolecular constituents such as polymers, surfactants, and/or other large molecules to generate composite materials. Mixing and processing of these solutions to attain a desired dispersion depends on how the nanoparticles can spread in these complex solutions, which in turn depends on how their motion is coupled to that of the macromolecular constituents. Thus, we used advanced computational techniques and microscopy and scattering experiments to study the dynamics of nanoparticles suspended in solutions of similarly sized polymers, which are well-characterized macromolecular crowders.

The outcomes from our project were focused on two main areas.

First, we used a computational modeling technique (multi-particle collision dynamics) to simulate the motions of nanoparticles in solutions of polymer chains and systematically explore the effects of local polymer backbone flexibility on nanoparticle and polymer dynamics.  The main outcomes from these studies are: (1) We observed evidence of a coupling mechanism whereby nanoparticles and polymer chains move in tandem through displacements about their center of mass on short time scales. This previously undiscovered coupling mechanism was found to provide a plausible explanation for the disagreement between previous experimental measurements and the predictions of theoretical models that do not account for this behavior. (2) We found that this mechanism was highly sensitive to the degree of local flexibility along the backbone of the polymer chains, observing that the degree of coupling was strongest for highly flexible polymers.  This finding indicates that the coupling of nanoparticle and polymer motions on short time scales may be influenced by factors that alter flexibility, such as the chemical composition of the polymers.

Second, in experiments we investigated the dynamics of nanoparticles in solutions of charged polymers (sodium poly(styrene sulfonate)). Here, the presence of charges along the monomer backbone reduces the local flexibility, which we expected to alter the coupling of the nanoparticle dynamics to the polymer motions based on our computational studies. The main outcomes from these studies are: (1) We showed that, in the absence of salt (where the effects of electrostatic interactions from the backbone charges are expected to be strongest), the dynamics of nanoparticles in charged polymer solutions exhibited an unusual non-monotonic (increasing, then decreasing) dependence on the polymer concentration. Our results suggested that this behavior was due to the distinctive charge-induced conformation of the polymers. (2) We used a combination of neutron scattering methods (small angle neutron scattering, neutron spin echo spectroscopy) to investigate how the conformation of the charged polymers in semidilute solutions affected local chain motions. Across a range of salt and polymer concentrations we found that the local chain motions were slowest where the structural correlations were strongest.

Broader Impacts:

This proposal supported the training of 1 PhD student (who defended his PhD in May 2022 and started a position as an industrial scientist at ExxonMobil Chemical) in experimental methods in soft matter science, including sample preparation, microscopy, rheology, and advanced scattering methods, and 2 PhD students in computational modeling methods, including molecular dynamics and multi-particle collision dynamics simulations. The PIs and their students participated in outreach efforts hosted by the University of Houston at the Houston Energy Festival (2019) and hosted by the Society of Rheology at the Houston Children?s Museum (2018), and were involved in helping to organize a virtual Texas Soft Matter meeting (2021); opportunities for in-person participation over the past three years were limited by the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic.
